And one problem biological theories of warfare is that, while they might
be able to explain specific outbreaks of violence, warfare is actually
much more than this. Warfare is a highly planned and organized activity,
The first psychologist to investigate war was William James, who wrote the
seminal essay "The Moral Equivalent of War" in 1910. Here James suggested
that warfare was so prevalent because of its positive psychological

discipline—a sense of cohesion, with communal goals. The "war effort"
